questions.text: Homeostasis is called as dynamic equilibrium because______

choices.text: All variables are given equal importance
Can achieve a constancy in extreme environmental challenge
The set-point for all homeostatic variables is always fixed
Body maintains an internal balance within fluctuating limits

questions.solution:
Homeostasis is called dynamic equilibrium because the body maintains an internal balance within fluctuating limits. It describes the maintenance of nearly constant conditions in the internal environment despite changes in the outside world.

A number of variables such as body temperature, blood sugar levels, blood pH, etc. are regulated within a range of values (homeostatic ranges) and not at fixed values.

These variables are not given equal importance. There is a hierarchy of importance so that the constancy of certain variables may be altered markedly to maintain others within their normal range. For example, respiratory or metabolic compensation to maintain blood pH.

The disruption of homeostasis either due to extreme environmental challenge or a breakdown of internal homeostatic mechanisms is termed as a disease.

questions.text: Which is a component of homeostatic control system?
questions.solution:
Stimulus, receptor and effector are all components of a homeostatic control system.

Components of homeostasis include:

  • Stimulus - It is a detectable change in the internal or external environment, such as change in temperature.
  • Receptor - It detects environmental changes.
  • Integrating centre
  • Effector - It is an organ or cell that acts in response to a stimulus.

questions.text: Feedback regulation is seen in ______

choices.text: The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins
Smell of food triggers secretion of salivary and gastric juices
An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels
The increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure

questions.solution:
Feedback regulation is seen in the increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure. This is because, in feedback regulation, the homeostatic response (increased heart rate) occurs after the change (decrease in blood pressure) has occurred.

On the other hand, in feedforward regulation, the homeostatic responses take place before the change has occurred. This is done in anticipation of the change to minimize fluctuations. Examples of feedforward regulation include:

  • The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins.
  • The smell of food triggers the secretion of salivary and gastric juices.
  • An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels.

questions.text: Positive feedback is seen in all except_____
questions.solution:
Positive feedback is seen in all except gastric secretion. It is under negative feedback control.

Negative feedback consists of certain changes that affect a deficient or excessive variable to pull it back to a certain mean value to maintain homeostasis. Most processes in the body are under negative feedback. For example, an increase in gastric acids leading to a decrease in gastric secretion. 

Positive feedback consists of changes that affect a variable to push it further away from a certain mean value. For example, an increase in LH leading to a further increase in LH. Instances, where positive feedback plays an important role are:

  • Clotting of blood
  • Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  • LH Surge
  • Action potential
  • Shock
  • Parturition

questions.text: On infusion of a large volume of blood, the MAP rises from 100 mmHg to 175 mmHg. Due to the baroreceptor feedback mechanism, the MAP falls down to 125 mmHg. Calculate the gain of the feedback system.
questions.solution:
The gain of the feedback system in the above case is -2.

The gain of the system is then calculated by using the following formula:

Gain = C/E

Here, C is correction achieved from the deviated value and E is the remaining error post-correction.

Calculation

  • The original value in the given case is 100 mmHg.
  • The deviated value in the given case is 175 mmHg.
  • The corrected value in the given case is 125 mmHg.
  • C is given by correction achieved from deviated value, Corrected value - Deviated value = 125 - 175 = -50 mmHg.
  • E is given by the remaining error post-correction, Corrected value - Original value = 125 - 100 = 25 mmHg.
  • Gain = -50/25 = -2.

The negative symbol indicates that the homeostatic mechanism acts in a direction opposite to the initial deviation.

questions.text: Plasma membrane in eukaryotes is made up of all except _______
questions.solution:
Plasma membrane in eukaryotes does not contain triglycerides.

The plasma membrane is composed almost entirely of proteins and lipids. The major lipids include:

  • Phospholipids: Lecithin, cephalin, phosphatidylserine
  • Sphingolipids: Sphingomyelin
  • Cholesterol

questions.text: Membrane fluidity is increased by ____.
questions.solution:
Membrane fluidity is increased by linoleic acid, an unsaturated fatty acid. All other options are saturated fatty acids. 

Longer and saturated fatty acids decrease the fluidity because their side chains are straight and interact more strongly with each other. Conversely, unsaturated fatty acids increase the fluidity because their side chains are kinked and less compact.

Cholesterol, also known as fluidity buffer helps to maintain the fluidity of the cell membrane.

questions.text: The sequence of vesicular transport in a cell is
questions.solution:
The sequence of vesicular transport in a cell is ER - Cis - Trans - Cell membrane.

Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) - It is the site of protein synthesis. Proteins are taken to the Golgi apparatus through transport vesicles.

Cis end of Golgi apparatus - Also called as receiving end, it is closest to RER

Trans end of Golgi apparatus - Also called as releasing end, it is furthest away from RER.

Cell membrane - Synthesised proteins within secretory vesicles are released into the extracellular space through the process of exocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following will test negative for all mitochondrial markers?
questions.solution:
Mature red blood cells will test negative for all mitochondrial markers are as they do not have mitochondria.

Lack of mitochondria is the reason why red blood cells exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate ATP.

questions.text: Gap junctions are found in all except ______
questions.solution:
Gap junctions are absent in adult skeletal muscles. 

Gap junctions are intercellular connections with a channel in between. They are present in excitable tissues such as cardiac muscle, smooth muscle and neurons but not in skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Tight junctions are not seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Tight junctions are not seen in cardiac muscle. 

Tight junctions form a water-tight seal between cells. They are characteristically seen in the following:

  • Intestinal mucosa
  • Renal tubules
  • Choroid plexus
  • Sertoli cells

Functions of tight junctions are:

  • Prevents the diffusion of macromolecules between cells.
  • Maintains cell polarity.
  • Seals the paracellular pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cell adhesion molecule (CAM)?
questions.solution:
Spectrin is a cytoskeletal protein but not a cell adhesion molecule.

Cells are attached to each other or to the basal lamina by cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). Some important classes of CAMs are: 

  • Integrins: heterodimers that bind to various receptors
  • IgG superfamily of immunoglobulins
  • Cadherins: Ca2+-dependent molecules that mediate cell-to-cell adhesion by homophilic reactions
  • Selectins which have lectin-like domains that bind carbohydrates

Clinical significance

  • Cancer cells have abnormal CAMs and hence cause decreased cell adhesion and allow individual cancer cells to detach from the parent cancer.
  • The decrease in the amount of E-cadherin maybe the reason for early metastasis of numerous tumors.

questions.text: Integrin connects with:
questions.solution:
Integrin connects with fibronectin.

Integrins are transmembrane glycoproteins (integral proteins) that allow cells to attach to extracellular matrix constituents such as laminin, fibronectin and collagen. It helps in linking the intracellular cytoskeleton functionally and structurally with the outside world.

questions.text: The force-generating proteins are _____.
questions.solution:
The force-generating proteins are dynein and kinesin. 

There are three superfamilies of proteins namely kinesin, dynein, myosin referred to as molecular motors.

The molecular motors are the force generating proteins as they move proteins, organelles, and other cell parts (collectively referred to as “cargo”) to all parts of the cell.

questions.text: An absent dynein arm in cilia can lead to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
An absent dynein arm in cilia leads to primary ciliary dyskinesia. Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

Ciliocytophthoria is the degradation of ciliated cells due to viral infections. It is not seen in primary ciliary dyskinesia.
